facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment of High Court of Punjab by Falshaw and Soni JJ dated 30th December 1949 upholding conviction under ss 302 and 307 read with s 34 IPC and confirming death sentence by Sessions Judge of Ferozepore on 20th July 1949

anchor.surface_text: APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 10 of 1950. Appeal by special leave from a judgment of the High Court of Punjab  Falshaw and Soni JJ.  dated 30th December, 1949, upholding the companyviction of the appellant under ss. 302 and 307 read with s. 34 of the Indian Penal Code and companyfirming the sentence of death passed against him by the Sessions Judge of Ferozepore on the 20th July, 1949, in Criminal Appeal Case No. 325 of 1949.

facts.text: Sessions Judge of Ferozepore passed death sentence against appellant Mohinder Singh on 20th July 1949 in Criminal Appeal Case No. 325 of 1949

anchor.surface_text: the Sessions Judge of Ferozepore on the 20th July, 1949, in Criminal Appeal Case No. 325 of 1949. Jai Gopal Sethi  R. L. Kohli, with him  for the appel- lant. K. Khanna, Advocate. General of the Punjab,  S. M. Sikri, with him  for the respondent. 1950. October 17.

facts.text: Bachittar Singh lodged complaint before Naib Tehsildar at Zira in January 1949 that tree belonging to him cut by 7 persons including Mohinder Singh

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in January, 1949, one Bachittar Singh, brother of Dalip Singh who is said, to have been murdered, lodged a companyplaint before the NaibTehsildar at Zira to the effect that a tree belonging to him had been cut by 7 per- sons including Mohinder Singh, the appellant.

facts.text: On 28th February 1949 date fixed for hearing before Naib Tehsildar Jita Singh and Dalip Singh attacked by Mohinder Singh and Gurnam Singh near Gurdwara at mid-day while returning from field

anchor.surface_text: On the 28th February, 1949, which was the date fixed for the hearing of the case before the Naib TehsiIdar, Jita Singh and Dalip Singh, the two brothers of Bachittar Singh, were attacked by the appellant and one Gurnam Singh, a lad of 17, near a Gurdwara at about mid-day, when they were returning from their field.

facts.text: Jita Singh carrying load of fodder on head Dalip Singh had sickles in hand

anchor.surface_text: Jita Singh was then carrying a load of fodder on his head while Dalip Singh had sickles in his hand. Jita Singh was the first to be at- tacked near a tailors shop by Mohinder Singh who fired at him from behind hitting him on the neck whereupon he fell down together with the bundle of fodder.

facts.text: Mohinder Singh fired at Jita Singh from behind hitting neck

anchor.surface_text: Jita Singh was the first to be at- tacked near a tailors shop by Mohinder Singh who fired at him from behind hitting him on the neck whereupon he fell down together with the bundle of fodder. Dalip Singh, who was following Jita Singh, then ran backwards and he was chased by Gurnam Singh round the outer boundary of a tank which was close by.

facts.text: Gurnam Singh chased Dalip Singh round tank Mohinder Singh confronted and shot Dalip Singh on chest

anchor.surface_text: Dalip Singh, who was following Jita Singh, then ran backwards and he was chased by Gurnam Singh round the outer boundary of a tank which was close by. Mohinder Singh ran on the other side of the tank in the opposite direction and companyfronted him and shot him with a gun on the chest whereupon he fell down.

facts.text: Gurnam Singh fired rifle at Dalip Singh ear from 4-5 feet while lying sideways Dalip died on spot

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, Gurnam Singh had also reached the spot and he fired with his rifle from a distance of about 4 or 5 feet near about Dalip Singhs ear while he was lying sideways. The injuries proved fatal and Dalip Singh died on the spot.

facts.text: Same day at 3 pm Jita Singh lodged FIR at PS Dharamkot 3 miles from village Augar charging Mohinder injury to him and Mohinder Gurnam murder of Dalip

anchor.surface_text: The same day at 3 p.m., Jita Singh went to the police station at Dharamkot, which is at a distance of 3 miles from village Augar, where the occurrence had taken place, and lodged a first information report, charging Mohinder Singh, with having caused injury to him, and Mohinder Singh and Gurnam Singh with the murder of Dalip Singh

facts.text: Police sent charge-sheet against Mohinder Singh and Gurnam Singh tried by Sessions Judge Ferozepore under 302 307 r/w 34 IPC

anchor.surface_text: and the police after investigating the case sent up a charge-sheet against the two accused persons. Thereafter they were tried by the Sessions Judge of Ferozepore under sections 302 and 307 read with section 34 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellant Mohinder Singh sentenced to death under 302 Gurnam Singh transportation for life under 302 due to youth both 3 years RI under 307/34

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was sentenced to death under section 302 and Gurnam Singh was sentenced to transportation for life under that section in view of his youth. They were also sentenced to 3 years rigorous imprisonment each under section 307 read with section 34 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Dalip Singh had 6 gunshot injuries as described by doctor in post-mortem

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Dalip Singh had 6 injuries altogether which are described by the doctor who performed the post- mortem on his body in these words- An irregularly round gun shot wound on the left temporal region, 1 diameter. The wound is 22 behind outer canthus of left eye, its upper portion is at a level with the top of the pinna of the left ear,

facts.text: Doctor opined two projectiles hit Dalip Singh injuries 1 and 2 by one entry head exit mastoid injuries 3-6 by another entry chest exit arm re-entry exit

anchor.surface_text: The doctor has stated in his evidence that in all two projectiles appeared to have hit Dalip Singh, and injuries Nos. 1 and 2 were caused by one of them, injury No. 1 being the wound of entrance and injury No. 2 being the wound of exit, With regard to the other 4 injuries, his evidence is as follows - Injury No. 3 is the wound of entrance of another projectile and No. 4 is the wound of its exit. Wound No. 5 is the wound of its re-entrance and wound No. 6 the wound of its final exit from the body.

facts.text: Jita Singh had 4 slight pellet injuries on back of neck and two abrasions below right elbow and knee

anchor.surface_text: Jita Singh had 4 slight injuries on the back of the neck which are said to have been caused by pellets and two abra- sions below the right elbow and right knee said to have been caused by blunt weapons.

facts.text: Police found empty cartridge case where Jita Singh fired at and 2 empty cartridge cases and blood-stained cap near Dalip body

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated here that when the investigating police officer arrived at the scene of occurrence, he found an empty cartridge case at the place where Jita Singh is said to have been fired at, and 2 empty cartridge cases and a blood-stained cap of a cartridge case near the place where the dead body of Dalip Singh was lying.

facts.text: Mohinder Singh produced 12 bore gun P-16 for which he held licence

anchor.surface_text: Later, when Mohinder Singh appeared before the police, he was asked whether he possessed a gun and he produced a 12 bore gun  exhibit P-16  for which he held a licence.

facts.text: Dr Goyle CID Lab opined gun P-16 had signs of firing but could not say when cartridge cases P-10 P-15 could have been fired from P-16 or similar no test done

anchor.surface_text: The gun and the empty cartridges were thereupon sent to Dr. Goyle, Director of the C.I.D. Laboratory, Phillaur, and the opinion that he submitted may be summed up as follows --The gun had signs of having been fired but he companyld number say when it was fired last. The cartridge cases P-10 and P-15 companyld have been fired through the gun P-16, but he companyld number say wheth- er they were actually fired from that particular gun or a similar gun or guns.

facts.text: Appellant denied firing and claimed alibi present at Zira Naib Tehsildar court on 28 Feb 1949

anchor.surface_text: After the close of prosecution evidence in the Ses- sions Court, the appellant was examined under section 342 of the Criminal Procedure Code, and he denied that he had fired at Jita Singh and Dalip Singh with the gun P-16 and that Gurnam Singh had fired at Dalip Singh with a rifle. He added that he was number present in village Augur at the time of the alleged occurrence but had gone to Zira to attend the Naib Tehsildars companyrt.

facts.text: Naib Tehsildar stated 6 or 7 persons appeared in court on 28 Feb 1949 proved taccavi loan application by appellant thumb impression passed orders same day

anchor.surface_text: The first witness was the Naib Tehsildar before whom Bachittar Singh had lodged the companyplaint, and he stated that when the case was called on the 28th February, 1949, 6 or 7 persons appeared in companyrt. He also proved an application for a taccavi loan which purports to have been filed by the appel- lant on the 28th February, 1949, and bears his thumb impres- sion. He further stated in his evidence that he had passed orders on that application on the 28th February

facts.text: Courts below held alibi not proved charges made out High Court not impressed by Dr Goyle evidence

anchor.surface_text: Both the companyrts below have held that the alibi has number been proved by satisfactory evidence and that the charges against the appellant have been made out. It seems that the learned Judges of the High Court were number at all impressed by the evidence of Dr. Goyle which they characterized as unsatisfactory

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on October 17 1950 by Fazl Ali J

anchor.surface_text: K. Khanna, Advocate. General of the Punjab,  S. M. Sikri, with him  for the respondent. 1950. October 17. The judgment of the companyrt was deliv- ered by FAZL ALI J.--This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment of the High Court of Punjab upholding the companyvic- tion of the appellant.
Appeal by special leave from a judgment of the High Court of Punjab  Falshaw and Soni JJ.  dated 30th December, 1949, upholding the conviction

concepts.interpretation: Court entertains criminal appeal by special leave in cases of substantial and grave injustice, disregard of legal process, or violation of natural justice principles.

The appellant was sentenced to death under section 302 and Gurnam Singh was sentenced to transportation for life under that section in view of his youth. They were also sentenced to 3 years rigorous imprisonment each under section 307 read with section 34 of the Indian Penal Code.

concepts.interpretation: Prosecution must prove entire case including fundamental points like shots fired by two persons with specific weapons at close range.

concepts.unlisted_description: Applies equally to prosecution and defence plea like alibi

1950. October 17. The judgment of the court was delivered by FAZL ALI J.--This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment of the High Court of Punjab upholding the conviction

issues.text: Whether the prosecution proved by expert evidence that it was likely or at least possible for the injuries to have been caused with the weapon with which and in the manner in which they are alleged to have been caused

anchor.surface_text: in a case where death is due to injuries or wounds caused by a lethal weapon, it has always been considered to be the duty of the prosecution to prove by expert evidence that it was likely or at least possible for the injuries to have been caused with the weapon

issues.text: Whether the prosecution proved the whole of its positive case, including that two shots were fired at Dalip Singh by two persons with a gun and a rifle from close range

anchor.surface_text: It is elementary that where the prosecution has a definite or positive case, it must prove the whole of that case. In the present case, it is doubtful whether the injuries which are attributed to the appellant were caused by a gun or by a rifle.

issues.text: Whether there is substantial and grave injustice warranting interference by the Supreme Court in this criminal appeal under Article 136
Whether the plea of alibi put forward by the appellant has been disproved applying the reasonable standard of proof required for both prosecution and defence cases

arguments.claim: Appellant did not fire at Jita Singh and Dalip Singh and was not present at village Augur but at Zira Naib Tehsildar court

anchor.surface_text: After the close of prosecution evidence in the Ses- sions Court, the appellant was examined under section 342 of the Criminal Procedure Code, and he denied that he had fired at Jita Singh and Dalip Singh with the gun P-16 and that Gurnam Singh had fired at Dalip Singh with a rifle. He added that he was not present in village Augur at the time of the alleged occurrence but had gone to Zira to attend the Naib Tehsildars court.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court not happy with manner of disposal by lower courts, noted disregard of reasonable standard of proof but acquitted primarily on prosecution failure

arguments.claim: Alibi proved by Naib Tehsildar testimony, taccavi loan application with thumb impression filed and orders passed on 28th February 1949

anchor.surface_text: The first witness was the Naib Tehsildar before whom Bachittar Singh had lodged the complaint, and he stated that when the case was called on the 28th February, 1949, 6 or 7 persons appeared in court. He also proved an application for a taccavi loan which purports to have been filed by the appel- lant on the 28th February, 1949, and bears his thumb impres- sion. He further stated in his evidence that he had passed orders on that application on the 28th February

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e manner in which they are al- leged to have been caused. It is elementary that where the prosecution has a definite or positive case, it must prove t

arguments.court_reasoning: Lower courts held alibi not proved by satisfactory evidence

arguments.claim: Firing must have been from 600 to 1200 yards away based on Taylors medical jurisprudence and Hatchers ballistics as projectile passed through without shattering
Alibi not proved by satisfactory evidence and charges against appellant made out

anchor.surface_text: Both the courts below have held that the alibi has not been proved by satisfactory evidence and that the charges against the appellant have been made out.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to appear before the Naib Tehsildar on the 28th February, 1949, which was the date fixed for dealing with Bachittar Singhs companyplaint. Ordinarily

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court found gap in prosecution evidence on material part and failure to prove by expert evidence

arguments.claim: Evidence of Dr Goyle unsatisfactory and not confident that gun P-16 used in causing injuries to Dalip Singh

anchor.surface_text: It seems that the learned Judges of the High Court were not at all impressed by the evidence of Dr. Goyle which they characterized as unsatisfactory and they were not also confident that the gun, exhibit P-16, had been used in causing the injuries to Dalip Singh.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e date fixed for dealing with Bachittar Singhs companyplaint. Ordinarily and without looking at anything else, there should have been numberhing impro

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agreed High Court felt inadequate explanation for puzzling injuries

arguments.claim: Nature of injuries on Dalip Singh puzzling: blackened entry to brain but no shatter, through body without extensive damage despite close range

anchor.surface_text: Another difficulty which is created in this case is the nature of injuries found on the body of Dalip Singh What kind of bullet it was which, though it had blackened the area where it entered the brain showing that it had been fired from not far away, did not shatter the brain we do not know.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to appear before the Naib Tehsildar on the 28th February, 1949, which was the date fixed for dealing with Bachittar Singhs companyplaint. Ordinarily

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court shared the feeling of puzzling features and required expert evidence

arguments.claim: Duty of prosecution to prove by expert evidence that injuries likely or possible with alleged weapon and manner

anchor.surface_text: in a case where death is due to injuries or wounds caused by a lethal weapon, it has always been considered to be the duty of the prosecution to prove by expert evidence that it was likely or at least possible for the injuries to have been caused with the weapon

arguments.claim: Prosecution must prove the whole of its definite or positive case

anchor.surface_text: It is elementary that where the prosecution has a definite or positive case, it must prove the whole of that case. In the present case, it is doubtful whether the injuries which are attributed to the appellant were caused by a gun or by a rifle.

arguments.claim: Injuries to Dalip Singh more likely caused by rifle than gun but prosecution case is appellant used gun P-16

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, it seems more likely that they were caused by a rifle than by a gun, and yet the case for the prosecution is that the appellant was armed with a gun and, in his examination, it was definitely put to him that he was armed with the gun P-16.

arguments.claim: Prosecution failed to prove by expert evidence that two shots fired at Dalip Singh by two persons with gun and rifle from close range

anchor.surface_text: It is only by the evidence of a duly qualified expert that it could have been ascertained whether the injuries attributed to the appellant were caused by a gun or by a rifle and such evidence alone could settle the controversy as to whether they could possibly have been caused by a fire-arm being used at such a close range as is suggested in the evidence.

arguments.claim: Oral evidence of three witnesses unreliable: chance witnesses not independent, one partisan and improbable after being shot from behind

anchor.surface_text: the error which has been committed by the courts below is to ignore the gap and decide the case merely upon the oral evidence of 3 witnesses, two of whom are mere chance witnesses and not altogether independent persons, and the evidence of the third witness is open to criticism on the ground of his partisanship as well as the improbability of his having been able to see the firing at his brother after he had himself been shot at the back of the neck.

arguments.claim: Substantial and grave injustice done warranting interference under Article 136 as conviction despite missing material prosecution evidence
Plea of alibi disposed in disregard of principle that standard of proof same as prosecution: reasonable standard
Alibi supported by probability, written document, affirmative witness evidence despite relation

holdings.text: In a case where death is due to injuries or wounds caused by a lethal weapon, it is the duty of the prosecution to prove by expert evidence that it was likely or at least possible for the injuries to have been caused with the weapon with which and in the manner in which they are alleged to have been caused; here, the evidence adduced falls short of proof on this material part.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court noted puzzling injuries without adequate explanation; court applies established duty on prosecution for expert evidence and finds failure in this case.

holdings.text: Where the prosecution has a definite or positive case, it must prove the whole of that case; here, doubtful whether injuries caused by gun or rifle, more likely rifle, and failed to prove two shots by two persons with gun and rifle from close range via expert evidence.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies elementary principle to facts: prosecution case specifies gun by appellant and rifle by co-accused at close range, but injuries inconsistent without expert proof.

holdings.text: Courts below erred in ignoring gap in prosecution evidence on fundamental point and relying solely on oral evidence of three witnesses, two chance and not independent, third partisan and improbable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Identifies evidentiary gap on shots and weapons; critiques oral evidence credibility and lower courts' reliance thereon.

holdings.text: Present case warrants interference under Article 136 as substantial and grave injustice done by convicting despite wanting evidence on material part of prosecution case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Pritam Singh precedent; finds grave injustice from conviction on incomplete evidence.

holdings.text: Standard of proof required for plea of alibi is the same reasonable standard as applied to prosecution evidence; lower courts disregarded this in disposing of alibi.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Notes lower courts' error in alibi evaluation despite acquittal on other grounds; supported by alibi evidence probability, document, witness.

anchor.surface_text: Pritam Singh v. The State 1 , will number entertain a criminal appeal except in special and exceptional cases where it is manifest that by a disregard of the forms of legal process or by a violation of the principles of natural justice or o

precedents.cited_proposition: This Court will not entertain a criminal appeal except in special and exceptional cases where it is manifest that by a disregard of the forms of legal process or by a violation of the principles of natural justice or otherwise substantial and grave injustice has been done

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the present case comes within the rule laid down, because the appellant has been convicted notwithstanding the fact that the evidence is wanting on a most material part of the prosecution case. This is enough to dispose of this appeal

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal disposed of due to substantial and grave injustice from lack of proof on material part of prosecution case
